admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
trustfund:
TF028301-GEF1-CHINA WORK PROGRAM FOR
            NATURE RESERVES MANAGEMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is highly
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are high. Similarly, both performances
            by the Bank and Borrower are rated highly satisfactory, in
            light of the precise project identification, design, and
            supervision, as well as the timely, and adequate
            implementation performance, respectively. Regardless of
            success, some lessons may be drawn from the overall project
            design, and specific project components. By sequencing the
            implementation of the project, attention was mainly focused
            on training, and planning, diverting attention from
            infrastructure building, and in addition, limiting the time
            period (and probably) the impact of the management action
            phase. Instead, an early start on capacity building at
            project design, and the provision of on site technical
            assistance throughout implementation, would have further
            strengthened processes, and activities. Such framework,
            could also impact the nature reserve management planning,
            i.e., initial data collection, and analysis should focus on
            priority species, and habitats in order to identify short-
            to medium-term management actions, while a comprehensive
            inventory should be made during implementation of the
            management plan phase. Most importantly, funding by the
            central government for targeted conservation research,
            should be made available on a competitive basis, to meet the
            priority needs of nature reserves management.
